Q: How do I get my build to generate multi-line problem messages in VSCode? A:

Basically to match a multi-line problem message, in your tasks.json you have a "problemMatcher" where the "pattern" is not a single object but an array of objects; these are the patterns for the individual consecutive lines and they all will create separate child entries in the tree.

For instance, with my error output:

E "ide_core.c",L571/C16:        b_bufhd
|    Selection of a member from a non-structure is attempted.

I can use this matcher to match it:

            "problemMatcher": [
                {
                    "owner": "mcc",
                    "pattern": [
                        {
                            "regexp": "^E \"([^\"]*)\",L([0-9]+)\\/C([0-9]+): (.*)$",
                            "file": 1,
                            "line": 2,
                            "column": 3,
                            "message": 4,
                        },
                        {
                            "regexp": "^\\|(.*)$",
                            "message": 1,
                            "loop": true
                        }
                    ]
                },

(Reminder: Starting with an ordinary ECMAScript regular expression, which you can test at e.g. regex101.com, and may already have things internally that have been escaped with \, like the / and | in my example, since the regular expressions for "regexp" are going into a quoted string in a JSON file, after that you need to escape " -> \" and those \->\\.)

The last object in the "pattern" array can have a "loop" setting set to true which makes it repeat that line pattern on subsequent lines until the next line no longer matches. So in my example any further lines starting with | will continue to be handled.

But there is a catch: every line pattern has to have matched at least once for the problem matcher to be considered to have found a problem.

https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/debugtest/tasks#_defining-a-multiline-problem-matcher

They have a kind of strange case that they use for exposition, multiple separate error messages for the same file that are grouped by filename, which doesn't really fit the functional spec as suggested in the visual you linked, i.e. individual error messages that span multiple lines. Their presumable misunderstanding that this reflects maybe explains this strange limitation a bit.

Depending on the exact form of your messages maybe you can sort of cheese it to get what you want.

In my example, there are also single-line errors like:

E "ide_core.c",L405/C8: Integer constant expected.

This matches the first line pattern, but since it has no following line with |, this matcher doesn't match it. So I have to have a separate "problemMatcher" entry to match those.

However it can't just be a separate matcher with just the same first line pattern again as its whole "pattern", as that will take all the matches away from the multi-line matcher. I have to sort of spot an otherwise irrelevant thing that's specific to the single-line-only pattern and use it to create a more specific matcher for just the single line case. For instance in my multi-line error the message part on the first line only has a single identifier and the message part on the single line messages always have at least two words on the first line. So I can do:

                {
                    "owner": "mcc",
                    "pattern": 
                        {
                            "regexp": "^E \"([^\"]*)\",L([0-9]+)\\/C([0-9]+): +([^ ]+ [^ ]+.*)$",
                            "file": 1,
                            "line": 2,
                            "column": 3,
                            "message": 4,
                        }
                    
                },
            ],

Q: moving from C, how to implement doubly linked list in C++ using the c++ features? A:

There are two "main" ways to safely create dynamically allocated storage in C++.

1: Smart Pointers.
2: Containers.

These are distinct patterns, and each has its own "style" for implementing safe, non-leaking storage. You don't generally mix the two.

A doubly linked list is a container, so I would not use smart pointers to implement it.

I would note that std::list has all the properties of a doubly linked list and is therefore likely implemented that way in all standard implementations.

I struggle to find an elegent way to implement this with smart pointers instead.

The trouble is that each "frame" of the dynamically linked list is "owned" by a single object (the list), but has pointers from two other "frame"s (the previous and the next frame). So, trying to use smart pointers does not match the pattern that these smart pointers are used to implement.

I could implement it using shared pointers,

Do you mean std::shared_ptr?

but I heard that these should be saldom used and that you should attempt implementing using unique_ptr by default.

Yes. You are have spotted the contradiction in the pattern. If you have a doubly linked list then there are two pointers to each "frame". So you would either need to use a std::shared_ptr and have ownership of each frame shared between the prev/next frame (this is very painful as this introduces cycles with cycles), or you can use std::unique_ptr but here you can only have one owner so only one of the pointers (say next) is the owning pointer, while prev is a non owning pointer. This works but is an asymmetric pattern thus hard to think about and introduces its own complexities.

In this situation the best pattern (in my opinion) is a C pointer (between frames). The "frames" don't own each other they are just linked together. The container is the owner of all the "frames" and it is the responsibility of the container to manage the memory of all the frames via its constructors / destructors.

Some very good discussion about linked list implementations on Code Review

Q: How to add prefix and suffix to every element in array in Jinja2? A:

It can be done with builtin Jinja2 filters. Suppose arr holds the list, pre holds the prefix and suf holds the suffix. Then we have one-liner Jinja2 transformation:

{{ arr | map('reverse') | slice(arr|length, pre|reverse) | map('join') | map('reverse') | slice(arr|length, suf) | map('join') | join(',') }}

The key operation slice(arr|length, suf) puts each element into it's own nested list with the suf. Then map('join') can be used to concatenate each one. As for the prefix, do the same but with reverse .

If the macro was acceptable, it'd be much more straightforward:

{%- macro surround(arr, pre, suf) %}{% set comma=joiner(',') %}{% for x in arr %}{{comma()}}{{ pre ~ x ~ suf }}{% endfor %}{% endmacro -%}

Then use it like {{ surround(['host1', 'host2'], 'http://', ':8080') }}.

Q: SQLPlus saving to CSV File without Formatting A:

I'd say that it is SET ECHO OFF that's bothering you. Try it.

Also, perhaps you'd want to bookmark the following set of SET commands.

SET ECHO OFF
SET VERIFY OFF
SET TRIMSPOOL ON
SET TRIMOUT ON
SET LINESIZE 9999
SET PAGESIZE 0
SET FEEDBACK OFF
SET TIMING OFF
SET TIME OFF
SET LONG 10000

Found a workaround... I still don't understand how the default templates work, but I've tried until I give up. I just hard-coded a div style="right;" in the archive-product.php, closing the div just before the sidebar commanding lines. It's crude, I know, but it seems to do the trick.

Q: What is HTML and why is it important in web development? A:

HTML can be understood with a simple real-life example: a restaurant menu. When you open a menu, you immediately understand what the restaurant name is, which lines are section titles like “Starters” or “Main Course,” and which lines are individual food items with prices. That clarity comes from structure, not design. HTML plays the same role on a website by clearly defining what each piece of content is and how it relates to other content.

Key points explained through this example:

  • HTML gives structure to content, just like a menu organizes food into sections and items.

  • Browsers use HTML to understand meaning, such as what is a heading, paragraph, image, or link.

  • CSS only improves appearance, similar to colors and fonts on the menu, but it cannot exist without the menu itself.

  • JavaScript adds interaction, like ordering food online, but it still depends on the menu structure.

  • Search engines read HTML to understand and rank content, just like a customer scans a menu to decide what to order.

  • Accessibility tools rely on HTML, allowing screen readers to correctly read headings, buttons, and links.

In short, HTML is important because it creates the basic structure and meaning of a webpage. Without HTML, a website would have no organization, no clarity, and nothing for design or interactivity to build on.
